newsitem.title: CHINA: Chinese grain stores reach record - paper.
newsitem.headline: Chinese grain stores reach record - paper.

text.p: A 42 percent hike in the price the Chinese government pays farmers for their grain has helped push official purchases to a record so far in 1997, the China Securities newspaper said on Wednesday.
By the end of March 1997, grain purchases for addition to state reserves totalled 11.85 million tonnes, 2.41 million tonnes more than at the end of March 1996, it said.
Of this figure, 4.9 million tonnes was purchased by the central authorities, up 560,000 tonnes on 1996.
A further 4.87 million tonnes were purchased by city authorities, up 500,000 tonnes on 1996.
Central reserve authorities purchased 2.08 million tonnes, up 158,000 tonnes on the period to the end of March 1996.
There had been no recurrence of past problems, such as unwillingness of peasants to sell their grain, nor of having to issue "white strips" or IOU's, the paper said.
It did not say how much the farmers had been paid.

By the end of March, grain bureaux had sold 7.05 million tonnes of grain from the 1996 harvest into the market, a fall of 2.2 million tonnes on the same period of a year ago. Of that 2.62 million tonnes was sold at a state-set price, 247,000 tonnes less than in the same period of 1996.
City grain bureaux sold 2.72 million tonnes, 52,500 less than they had by the end of March 1996, the newspaper said.
Other sales accounted for 1.71 million tonnes, 440,000 less than at the same time last year, it said.
China's total 1996 grain harvest was an official record of 490 million tonnes.

Between September 1996 and April 20, 1997, a total of 6.25 million tonnes of grain had been transported from the northeast and Inner Mongolia to large and medium-sized cities and areas where grain shortages were available, it said.
By the end of March, 5.16 million tonnes of grain from the 1996 harvest had been added to grain bureau stocks, it said.
Stockpile figures are treated as a state secret in China.
